(If I was doing a finished product I'd still use laser photo paper)It's fast, quiet, and works seamlessly with all of my computer, and mobile, applications.One thing to note that frustrated me a bit was the scanner. Now follow with me on this before you judge. I've tried multiple times to scan remotely from my PC and it simply won't work while the machine is in sleep mode. It's like the network won't recognize the scan function while it sleeps. Then, I thought about it for a second. Why would I scan something if I wasn't standing by the printer putting whatever I want to scan on the machine? So unless I missing something, it really isn't a big deal.I also can't seem to scan multiple pages into one document as the model I purchased doesn't have the sheet feeder. The windows scanner app doesn't allow it, which is a pain in the neck and not Lexmark's fault. Happily, the mobile app that Lexmark provides does allow for this functionality, so there is an easy workaround.I do wish I would have gotten the sheet feeder though, so if you scan multiple page documents, don't be silly like me and say, "I don't need the sheet feeder," because you probably will.All in all, wonderful printer that I would highly recommend. 5-stars!

title: Better than expected
body: Better than expected. Easy to hook up and start using. Many helpful functions.

title: Solid multifunction - well-designed and well-built
body: The first thing you'll notice when you unbox this printer is that it's well-built and *solid*. It definitely doesn't have the flimsy, plastic-y feel some other printers have. However, it's also not as bulky as other business-level multifunction printers. Setup was ridiculously easy, according to the picture-only quick start guide: remove the shipping tape from it, plug it in, and turn it on. There is a mobile app you can use to configure your printer (Lexmark Mobile Assistant), but it's not really necessary.The touch screen is clear and responsive, and even with my fat fingers, I'm able to use it easily. The scanner is fast, able to scan and print a color page in less than 30 seconds from warm-up to page in hand. When it comes to printing, this thing is a machine gun. I printed a 10 page doc in less than 30 seconds, and while saying it is one thing, watching it print is something else. The prints are crisp and clear, with no toner smudging or dust anywhere.Someone else mentioned there's no USB cable included (the only cable in the box is the power supply), so be aware of that. I connected mine wirelessly, and as mentioned, setup was a snap and took less than 5 minutes. This is a really solid printer that does everything you'd expect, and does it well.

title: A very solid, capable, reliable, all-in-one monochrome printer
body: If you're in need of a monochrome printer that can also scan, fax and copy, this is one of the better all-in-one printers I've ever come across.Set-up is extremely easy. With that said, there's very little material to work with in the way of directions. However, if you've ever set-up a printer, you'll be fine. The touch screen is very easy to work through. So, really, no worries there.Overall, you're looking at less than 10 minutes set-up for most home offices, and no more than 25 for complex business settings.Functionally, I've yet to run across anything this doesn't do that is claimed in the overall product write-up.This is a somewhat compact all-in-one, but it's not necessarily small. With that said, it should fit well in most home offices and will certainly work in any business setting.Quality is very good. Printing is crisp, clear and without any manner of imperfections.The unit is fairly quiet, but not silent in operation.Overall, really, for the level this printer operates at, I find it to be one of the best options out there for home, small home office, small business, and medium sized business use.I'm very comfortable recommending this as a viable all-in-one solution.5 starsCheers!

title: Compact size
body: This is a conveniently sized compact printer for a small office but perfect for high output. I like that double sided printing is standard. It has a user friendly touch pad screen and high speed print capability. I also like the double sided scanning feature which is a great time saver as well.

title: Smallish footprint for a monochrome laser printer. Good connectivity options. Helpful setup process.
body: General: This product replaced a Brother multifunction printer. We also have a smaller "single function" Brother and also a Canon laser printer for comparison.This generation of printers is faster, easier to set up and more flexible than earlier generations (any make).Size matters. Printers are used less often these days for most people, so having a smaller footprint is important.Apart from price, you may wish to consider whether you need a color laser printer, which gives you a nicer appearance for presentation handouts, but will require more and specialized consumables.PRO- Small footprint- Supports hardwired ethernet as well as wireless, USB- Well-placed network security- Color LCD to well thought-out cues to aid with setup (see photo).- Fast . Appears to meet or exceed promised print rate at single side.- Unclear whether this printer is field upgradeable.- Not measured, but this printer seemed to be a little more stingy with power during printing that our two Brother printers (which are >7 years old).- At least as good or better than our Canon laser printer (which jams now and then and can be difficult to clear)CON- Appears to be only 2.4 WiFi networks- Minor difficulty reseating the print cartridge during initial installation. There is an interlock that prevents you from proceeding.- Unclear how the field upgrades work if made available.- A lot of setup software is needed. For Windows 7 (obsolete), for instance, it could not find a suitable driver online. A completely web-based installer vs. the supplied CD might have been easier. That said, it worked OK, though it puts more running tasks into your system (tray, notifications, etc.).- In testing, noticed that after it had put itself to sleep, the printer would power itself up and go through a warming or self-test procedure (but not print anything.) May have been a one-off glitch.- The paper Quick Start Guide was not as helpful as the onboard setup tips.- Unclear if it's EnergyStar 3.0 (final version, February 2020)TIPS and REMARKSTo ease setting up WiFi, use the optional Lexmark app to assist in setting up the WiFi connection. The app will take over your network connection briefly for this purpose -- similar to what Alexa or Google Home devices do during setup.The Lexmark device allows you to skip setting up its admin password. Because this occurs so early in the setup, it's not clear what it's for. Once you have it working, be sure to go back and set it up; otherwise, it's a risk to your network.Recommend contacting Lexmark RE field upgrade options before purchasing. Online documentation was not available at the time of this review.This generation of printers is faster, easier to set up and more flexible than earlier generations (any make).How well does the printer handle jams using 100% recycled paper? I haven't run into this predictable scenario yet. Stay tuned.Apart from price, you may wish to consider whether you need a color laser printer, which gives you a nicer appearance for presentation handouts, but will require more and specialized consumables.Why not five-star?Unable to evaluate the user manual or online FAQs and registration steps. This is not unusual for a new product evaluation, so it might be five-star in a month or two once this printer is fully launched in the market.

title: Great Printer For the Home or Office
body: This is a fantastic laser printer that is easy to set up and offers a variety of features. The printer comes very well protected with packaging that ensures the item will arrive in good order. First you have to remove about a dozen pieces of tape that keep the lids and compartment doors from opening during transit. The toner cartridge is already installed, but you have to open the toner compartment and remove a layer of shipping foam before operation.The printer includes a CD for installation. I connected my printer to the network via Ethernet cable and ran the installation software off the CD on my laptop. Once the software had been installed, I was also able to use the printer with my desktop. This was convenient because my desktop doesn't have a CD drive.The printer has a lot of features and comes in a compact size for a laser printer. It's an ideal choice for work, home office, or if you have a several school age children who have to print out assignments. There is a small touch screen on the printer that is easy to use. The large toner cartridge means you won't have to replace the toner for months. This is a good choice for all your printing needs.

title: Biggest headache ever
body: I ordered this for our new office since we didnâ€™t have a printer yet. We (my wife and I) had been doing all the office printing at home on an inkjet.I tested it at home the day it arrived. The setup isnâ€™t as quick and easy as Lexmark claims. There are no written instructions, just a page with pictures and arrows that seem to be trying to illustrate where all the packing tape is so you can remove it. There was plenty of that. When I removed the paper tray, a large piece came loose from underneath and fell off. It took several minutes to figure out how to reinstall that.Once I was sure all the tape was removed and got some paper loaded, I decided to try and go through the setup menu on the touch screen. It took about half a dozen attempts to navigate it correctly. It said something about using an app to set it up and I tried but was not successful. It wasnâ€™t until I did a manual setup that I got it to work. Then the app (which I had installed on my phone) was able to find it.I used my phone to print several test pages (including a couple of images) and it printed them quickly. They were the high quality that you would expect from a laser printer.Lexmark is a reputable brand and I would expect this to be a printer that will last a long time. I would also expect good customer service (I was tempted to call during setup).I think we will be satisfied with it. I'm giving it only four stars due to the difficulty with the setup.UPDATE 04/02/2020:We have stopped using this printer. It began jamming during every print job. Repeat every print job. The worst part is that there really isn't any jammed paper. It is always a sheet that didn't eject properly, but I have to take the printer apart looking for the jam in order to clear the error code. This includes removing the paper tray which always causes a piece to fall out. To put it back together I have to turn the printer on its side. I have to do this every single time. It has been at least 10 days since I got a print job without a paper jam. I'm convinced the problem centers around the part that keeps falling out. But since there was no user guide or manual and I can't find this printer on Lexmark's website, I have no idea how to fix the problem.

title: Outstanding Printer
body: Lexmark has an enviable reputation for high-performance printers. After using this fine new product, I can see why.This is an outstanding printer. It has laser exactitude and high speed. It's got excellent connection options. For example, one can connect to a desktop via a cable while using wifi for remote access, laptops etc. It's got all the familiar functions one needs in a small business office: copy, scan, fax etc.I've only had this printer briefly so I'm not yet able to comment on durability or its use of toner. Should anything not meet expectations I'll update my review. Nonetheless, based on the Lexmark reputation and my early experience, I highly recommend this printer, which has a place in my office effective immediately.

title: Awesome all-in-one machine with versatile scanning options
body: I had this office quality monochrome laser printing/scanning/copy machine set up and operating in less than 20 minutes without a hitch. A software CD is included, but it wasn't needed for setup. Once we had it connected to our WiFi network, our Mac iOS and Linux computers recognized and operated it as a printer right away. The Mac recognized the scan function too.Speaking of scanning, this machine does both sheet fed scanning and flatbed scanning/copying/faxing. All functions are operable directly from the touch screen control panel (which is simple and intuitive) as well as from your computer.There are several connectivity options, including corded via USB or Ethernet cable, or WiFi wireless. The most secure means to print documents is via corded connection, but Lexmark includes "full spectrum security" as an option.I didn't put a timer on it to see if it really prints 42 pages per minute, but it is fast, and the print quality is of course laser printer sharp. And it does two-sided printing.There's a lot to like here. The only minor negative is that it is a monochrome printer (black toner only) and not full color. But I owned a color laser printer for years and was never too impressed with its color output or reproduction. I think ink jet printers are better at that. Laser printers excel at super sharp and cost effective black and white printing, and laser printed pages are water resistant---they don't smear and spread if a bit of water drops on them like ink jet ink tends to do.

title: Updated review
body: 1. The printer does not include any instructions for set-up. It only includes a one page (two-sided) series of illustrations showing you were to remove all of the packing material.2. I went to the Lexmark website to find set-up instructions (driver is supplied as a CD-ROM, but none of my computers have a CD-ROM drive so I needed to download the drivers). Searching on their website for information yields no results for this model.3. Fumbling through the on-screen set-up, selecting to run initial set-up just returns you to the main menu. It doesn't do anything.4. The "troubleshooting" selection only has two choices. print test pages and cleaning the scanner5. Even a Google search for help turns up no results. Its like this printer doesn't even exist and is a figment of my imagination.6. Purchased a printer cable to connect directly to the computer. Finally found the correct driver on the Lexmark site and downloaded it (it isn't labeled for this specific model I ended up just selecting what appeared to be the newest driver available). Was finally able to print directly connected. Wi-Fi still won't set up, even though my Wi-Fi network was able to find the printer and connect it. Neither my laptop or my desktop can "find" the printer to connect via wi-fi.7. Keep getting an "E-mail SMTP server not set up" error message each time I print. When to the Embedded Web Server site and cannot see any way to get rid of the error. Cannot "log in" to the web server site because I do not have a log in set up. Google search returns results for how to get rid of the error, but you can't follow those directions without logging in, which I can't do.The print QUALITY, when it does print, is fine. It is possible I just got a bad unit and my problems are not indicative of the model overall. But the lack of easily discernable instructions ANYWHERE for this model, and the fact that no site returns results for this model when looking for things like toner is a problem.

title: Great For Your Home Office!
body: We were looking to replace our existing multi-function printer in my wife's home office. We were having wireless connection problems and I really wanted to upgrade to a laser printer. This was an excellent choice!What I Like:Lexmark brand has a great reputation for making quality printers. We expect to get several years of use from this unit.Combines print, scanning and fax capabilities - perfect for the home office.Print quality is excellent - as is expected from a laser printer.Print output is also very good - multiple pages print much more rapidly than the inkjet it replaced!Refill toner cartridge is reasonably priced - especially when compared to toner for color printers.Can connect via wireless by connecting to local wifi network or directly via a USB or ethernet cable - nice to have several options - we opted to connect to our WIFI network so I can print to it as well from my laptop.Really nice printer and very happy with it - highly recommend!What I would change:Printer is considerably larger than the inkjet unit it replaces. We kept the old unit on a cart under her desk - this is too big so we put it on one end of her "L" shaped desk. A smaller form factor would be great but not a deal breaker.Great printer - highly recommend!

title: Quick and easy setup!
body: This is my second Lexmark printer, and the company never disappoints. What I like about his model is that is indicates when your toner cartridge is low on toner or the imaging unit needs to be replaced. It prints crisp printing. Easy to set up just setup Wifi on printer the access printer with mobile app. Quick and easy.

title: I can't say if it good because is not working
body: It turned on made some noises and immediately turned off. I will say that it arrived in precarious conditions the box was destroyed and missing a section, almost like something puncture the box and made a hole. It doesnt help that we had rain for a few days and the box was left at my back door under the rain until my husband who is the first to arrive got home from work. He said that the box was so wet it fall apart.

title: It works with wired ethernet, has safety mark, poor instructions
body: I had a little trouble setting this up. The instructions are graphical so that they work all the different languages worldwide. The first steps go through getting it out of the box, removing all the shipping tape and padding, putting paper in it and the like. At step 12, it basically says turn it on. Then in step 13 there is a picture of the CD and an arrow to a laptop. My laptop doesnâ€™t have a CD drive. So I tried using it on a desktop Windows 10 PC and it couldnâ€™t find the printer. I assume there was a missing step somewhere that was to allow the printer to access my local WiFi network. Since I have a wired ethernet as well as WiFi, I chose to make a wired connection so that I could go to the next step in the setup program. It did find the printer and that allowed me to go further. I did have to do a bit of troubleshooting to actually get it to print. I got some error message about something (SMTP?) not being set up. I kept trying to print and I thought it still wasnâ€™t working until I went to the room where the printer was located and found that it had been printing and double sided at that. I seem to remember it asking me at some point if I used the wireless app to set up the printer. Since I didnâ€™t have a wireless app that I was aware of, I said no. Notice in the lower right corner of the instructions there is an I with arrow pointing to a WWW for I assume information. Does this mean, if you need help search the web? A web might be helpful. On plus side, the printer works fine, with good print quality. I assume that I will get the wireless part working at some point.

title: Why do printer manufacturers assume everyone employs an IT department?
body: Printers are supposed to be patient servants who sit idle, but snap to attention when you need them. They do seem too if you have a wired connection. Adding Wifi seems to reduce the printer's IQ by half. Unless you have your own IT department or a 12 year old close by to rescue you. Now that that's out of the way, here are my impressions of this Lexmark B3340 so far. I was looking for a replacement for my Cannon, that was most of all intuitive and whose Wifi just plain worked every time. Unboxing seemed promising but suspect since documentation included one sheet of printed media and a DVD. The single sheet of "instructions" contained no words, just a few cave wall drawings with a helpful bent page indicator in the lower right hand corner indicating the need to turn the page over to continue. Good thing, I never would have noticed it was printed on both sides! Step 12 indicates you need to turn the printer on. The final step indicates you insert the DVD into your laptop. If only laptops still had DVD readers. In my Apple world those are barely even remembered. So there we both sat in awkward silence.There is a tiny, single line display so I decided to break the ice and start pushing the few buttons there. It asked if I wanted to set it up using an app. Yes please. I downloaded the only Lexmark app I could find onto my phone, but that proved to be a dead end. I used my iMac to try to locate drivers for the B3340 and finally wading through microscopic online print and charts seemed to find what I needed so clicked the hyperlink for Mac. Nothing downloaded. I connected the printer to my desktop to see if that might make a love connection. I thankfully had the correct cable. Would have been nice if Lexmark had included one but maybe no one does that any more. Though others seem to make even a tiny effort to give you a modicum of direction. I opened my Printer preference tab, and by golly, it had recognized the new printer. Clicking on some options seemed promising but still no directions. I went back to that single line display and started clicking through and eventually found an option to connect to Wifi. It found my network thankfully and asked for my password. I hoped there might be a more handy input method. But no, you need to go through small a, capital A, small b capital B, etc. for each part of your password. Mine dutifully is 10 characters long so it was a lot of tapping. Eventually all was set up, and I directed the computer to print a page and selected the Lexmark. Thankfully it instantly printed the page, though the quality seemed a little light and non-crisp. Imagining there were internal adjustments I went back to single line display, but nothing there. In the mean time the printer went into sleep mode. I opened the Printer choices but nothing helpful there. After pushing the back arrow on the printer it said it was "ready" and fully awake. Thats when, in the Printer section under the "general" tab, there was a tiny box that said it would take you to the printer web site. I bit, and although it's not obvious at all, there are nests of settings that will adjust your printer, including print quality and darkness level. I made the adjustments, printed another page and the page was beautiful. I was interrupted but returned to make sure all was in order, tried to print another page but nothing. It said it couldn't find the printer. Ten minutes later, the page printed.Over all, this seems to be a solid relatively compact printer. It says it's made out of steel though the exterior seems like hard plastic. The single line of display gives basic information only after lots of clicking and little intuitive guidance. Once all is set up to the settings of your choice, it seems promising. I cancelled sleep mode but it still seems to doze off and not print wirelessly on command. I'll keep tinkering. In conclusion, unit build seems solid, compact and unencumbered by buttons and blinking lights. Five stars there. As for helpful setup directions or any guidance I would give it zero stars if possible. I believe this will prove to be a solid, reliable printer. As long as I don't need to wake it up by physically pushing a button on the controls, and the wifi proves reliable, I should be happy. If you're reading Lexmark, can't you simply include a second piece of printed instructions that gives a buyer even a scrap of guidance? At least for customers who exist in the Apple universe, or with Windows laptops that lack DVD access?

title: Great monochrome laser for the home/small office
body: This is a compact, somewhat lightweight black & white laser printer. No scanner, fax, or copier. But as a printer it is excellent. Print speeds are fast at just about 1.5 seconds per page and the built-in duplexer is great. The instructions are just pictures, which can be a bit confusing, but once you have the printer out of the box they make more sense. This only comes with a power cable so if you're going to connect directly to a computer you will need a printer cable (that funky cable with a squarish connector). Because of all our devices we went with the wireless option for connectivity. The 2-line monochrome screen is used to set it up (date, time, time zone, connect to network). Again, no instructions. If you've set up a printer before this is not terrible, but a user manual would have made it much better. Do note that your network has to be 2G and not 5G. It does come with a CD but I prefer to download the latest from the manufacturer's website. This is a 100MB download for the full package. The Lexmark app installed fine on my Android tablet (Samsung) and I was able to print from there as well. This is a simple but very nice B&W laser that works well for any home office or even a small business office.

title: Great Desktop Laser Printer!
body: Needed a desktop printer for my office. I often print reports, emails, etc and don't want to go to the larger network printer down the hall to retrieve them. A local desktop printer is the perfect solution and this was a great choice!What I Like:Lexmark brand has a great reputation for making quality printers. I expect to get several years of use from this unit.Print quality is excellent - as is expected from a laser printer.Print speed is also very good - large reports print nearly as quickly as the huge printer down the hall!Refill toner cartridge is reasonably priced - more so than toner for color printers.Can connect via wireless by connecting to local wifi network or directly via a USB or ethernet cable - nice to have several options - I opted for a direct cable connection from my PC.Really nice printer and very happy with it - highly recommend!

title: A great little printer!
body: This wireless laser printer produces 2 sided printing and can be used with a mobile device. The paper feed has a 100 page capacity and the printer is capable of producing up to 40 copies per minute. This unit is very sturdily constructed and works beautifully! It's a nice, compact size weighing only 23 pounds that will fit easily into any office where space is limited and it needs only a very minimal amount of maintenance compared to many other brand models. It has Wi-Fi , USB and Ethernet connectivity capabilities. This printer is a quality investment for any small business or home office. I recommend it!Â

title: Great Printer
body: Great printer, easy to set up, prints on both sides.. I was able to set this up to print my chest since my old printer was malfunctioning. Very happy with product.

title: Incredibly fast printing, clean black and white pages, easy setup
body: I love this laser printer from Lexmark. It prints incredibly fast and the pages are perfect. Blacks are smooth and dark while the white page is clean and smudge free. Setup was almost a breeze. I did have trouble connecting to wifi but it eventually worked out. The printer does make a little grunt after each round of printing, but I'm assuming that's normal. I removed the drum and reseated it a few times without any difference in this response. Otherwise, everything works well.Ignore other reviews that say this printer can hold an extra large toner that prints 6000 pages. I have confirmed with Lexmark that this particular model, B2338adw, cannot use that cartridge. The standard cartridge prints up to 3000 pages which is excellent for most people. The included starter cartridge prints 1500 pages. Unfortunately, this printer doesn't seem to be able to hold generic toner cartridges so you are locked into the Lexmark cartridges and prices.I prefer this laser printer over my inkjet printer. I used to set my inkjet to print in grayscale only because the ink is expensive and I don't print photos or need color for personal use. My inkjet is now in the closet. I'm pleased with the performance of this printer and would recommend it to my own family and friends.

title: Stopped working after first cartridge change
body: I ordered the brand new ink cartridge with the printer. The first cartridge lasted 6mo., and when it ran dry, I put in the new cartridge. it is a Lexmark cartridge, it says it is for my printer, yet my printer says incompatible cartridge. Now it will not work. I updated the system, through it was just built in Sept of last year. So stupid. I hate printers. They are built to break.

username: Leah Maines, best-selling, award-winning author, actor, and editor
title: Good printer
body: The Lexmark Monochrome Laser Printer is a very good printer for the price. I have several printers, and I like the Lexmark brand. This printer prints only in black/grayscale. However, that is fine for most of my home office needs. It prints very fast. The print quality is good. The paper tray holds a fair amount of paper. It prints wirelessly with no problems. Setup is easy. Iâ€™m very happy with this printer

title: Disposable
body: I didn't do my research before ordering this printer. In this day and age, I didn't really think that I would have to because usually you can find aftermarket toner cartridges on the cheap, but I'm having trouble finding toner cartridges for the Lexmark B2338adw Monochrome Laser Printer other than the $87 Lexmark return cartridge here on Amazon.If you do the math, that means that the printer is worth about $20 and the toner is worth $90! To be fair, the starter toner is a specially loaded toner cartridge with far less toner than the regular one, so it could be argued that the printer is $50 - maybe. But if you think about it, you could easily make a case for just ordering a new printer every time the toner runs out, rather than using the same printer and ordering new toner each time.I feel like this is deceiving. It would be far more honest to sell the printer with a REAL CARTRIDGE that is loaded full and charge the full price - that way you would know what it was going to cost you in real world dollars and perhaps more importantly, you could comparison shop and see what it actually costs compared to other printers. The REAL price of this printer is the price of the printer PLUS a toner cartridge which is closer to $200 than $100.Otherwise, this looks like a decent laser printer that will handle heavy printing loads and is easy to set up with Windows or Mac. But I am so put off by the marketing and price of the cartridges that I don't know if I trust the company with my business.Before you school me on the fact that all printer companies do this, I am aware that it is a common practice - but I have never seen it quite so blatant or so costly. Usually you can bypass the printer company's overpriced toner or ink and save money. But for whatever reason, there appear to be no choices except Lexmark's expensive toner. I'd shop around and find a printer that isn't going to cost quite so much in consumables as time goes on.

title: Perfect for home use and multiple options for printing wirelessly
body: This Lexmark B2338adw Print Only Monochrome Laser Printer is perfect for home use and has multiple options for printing from your computer, your phone or your tablet.Understand that this is a laser printer. Laser printers print very differently from ink jet printers. It uses powdered toner which is attracts to the paper via an electric charge. A fuser permanently fuses the toner to the paper. Hence, there are no print heads or liquid ink. This process makes a laser printer and attractive choice for people who do not print large amounts or frequently as there are no print heads to get clogged or ink to dry up.Although there are color laser printers, this is a monochrome printer so only one toner cartridge, which is easy to install and replace and all of the toner is available for use as laser printers don't need priming, as ink jet printers do. Laser printers also produce incredibly crisp prints.One thing to note is that the toner cartridge for this printer is currently ~$90. Before you gasp, realize that the toner cartridge is rated for about 3,000 pages. There is a greater initial outlay for a laser printer toner cartridge but you don't generally replace them as often as ink jet cartridges. This printer comes with a starter toner cartridge installed, which is rated for about 1,500 pages.You can use this printer directly connected to your computer via a USB printer cable (NOT included), over your wifi network or as a wired network printer via an ethernet cable (NOT included.) Lexmark has a free app called the Lexmark Mobile Assistant to help you set the printer up. I have an android phone and I downloaded the app but for some reason, it couldn't find the printer. I didn't try for long because you can actually set it up using the control panel on the printer. You just need to know the name of your wifi network and the password. The printer connected instantly to my wifi network.Next, I tried installing the software on the included CD but again, ran into some issues with the software not finding the printer. I skipped that and went into my Windows Control Panel, selected Hardware and Sound, and then selected Advanced Printer Setup. It found the printer and when I selected it, Windows automatically installed the drivers for the printer and prompted me to print a test page to ensure it was working properly. The test page printed instantly and perfectly.If you have a Chromebook, you won't be able to connect the printer to your computer via a USB printer cable. Instead, you will use Google Cloud Print, which you will need to set up. You can also print wirelessly via Apple AirPrint, Mopris Print Service and Lexmark Mobile Print so you have a lot of options for printing from your phone or tablet.This is a printer only. It doesn't scan or copy as it is not an all-in-one printer. It does, however, have auto duplexing, which is automatic, double sided printing. It has a 250 sheet paper tray and a multi-purpose feeder for envelopes and specialty papers. It prints very quickly - even double sided pages. Print quality is excellent.My only complaint is that, like many printers these days, there is no printed user manual included. You can download it from the Lexmark website, though. While you are there, note that there is a firmware update available for this printer. You'll need to download the update and follow the directions carefully to install the update. Firmware updates are important and shouldn't be ignored so take time to do this.

title: High quality printer with full AirPrint support for the Mac and iPhone
body: This is an excellent printer for Mac users, especially if you have in iPhone. There is a two page cartoon showing how to unpack it, and the only confusing thing is that there is both a toner cartridge and an imaging unit into which the toner cartridge fits. When the printer arrives, both items are installed but with packing tape and pads surrounding them and they must be removed. The cartoons are not all that helpful in figuring out what to remove, but it is fairly obvious when you have the item in your hand. Just make sure all the tape and foam padding are removed and replace the imaging unit first, and then put the toner cartridge in next.The software setup is trivial if you have an iPhone. Download the Lexmark Mobile Print app from the app store and follow the prompts. I was done in less than a minute and the printer was then available via air print on all the other mac computers and phones in the house. The WIFI on this printer is highly stable.The reason I gave this only four stars is that Lexmark charges too much for its toner cartridges. Indeed, the toner cartridge for this printer costs more than the printer! Furthermore, the printer comes with a starter toner cartridge that will only last a few months at most. So my strong recommendation is to buy the printer + toner package. It will save you about $20.That complaint noted, this is an outstanding and reliable printer. For mac users it is especially nice because AirPrint has been fully implemented, which is not the case for many printers I have bought which claim to support it, but have only a partial implementation.

title: Lexmark B2338 Print Only Monochrome Duplex Laser Printer
body: I switched to laser printers because I rarely print in color or make copies and the constant expense of color cartridges that were little used but dried-out anyway seemed a wasteful use of limited resources. This printer has a USB and an Ethernet port so it can be connected wirelessly or through a wired network or a computer.The printer creates crisp clean output and preferences regarding resolution, darkness, brightness, etc. can be selected by the user. This device arrives with a toner cartridge that is stated to print 1500 copies which is half the regular cartridge (B231000) capacity of 3000 copies. If interested, there is also a high-yield cartridge available.Printing can be accomplished through any device connected to the printerâ€™s network. To use a mobile device, like a smartphone or tablet, the Lexmark Print app must be loaded. In Windows 10 no app is neededâ€“ just set up like any other printer. Details of my experience configuring the printer follow but in summary so far the printer is fast, the print quality is excellent and it works reliably whether printing from my wireless phone and laptop as well as my wired desktop PC.Following the two page visual instructions included in the box, I unpacked the printer and plugged in the power cord. The 2 by 1/2 inch illuminated display window statedâ€”setup using the mobile app. At the Apple app store I installed the Lexmark Mobile Assistant.The app instructed I should go to Settings on iPhone, find printer name shown on the printer display and connect to my local WiFi network using my network passphrase. Then I returned to the app and followed the remaining steps. If not planning to connect to WiFi, connect to a wired network using the Ethernet port or connect directly with a USB cable. These cables are not included.At this point it is ready to print wirelessly. On my desktop the printer was immediately recognized by Windows 10 so I did not load the included software disc. As mentioned above to print with my smartphone I loaded the Lexmark Print app. Once the mobile app is loaded the printer appears in the Sharing option for all apps that support printing.No printed manual is included but PDFs for a Quick Start Guide along with a very detailed User Manual are available at the company website along with information about firmware updates, FAQs, etc.If security is a concern a Pin number can be established. In the configuration settings a pin number may be created that applies to all jobs or individually at print time. In either case there is no output until the user types in the pin number at the printer console. Printing can be restricted to network users and/or local accounts.Also the user can erase (sanitize) printer memory (automatically saved image) to avoid sensitive documents being reprinted without authorization. This is a complex feature detailed in the user manual. Decent features at this price point.

title: Printer is making a grinding noise
body: The printer makes a grinding noise right after printing. Have checked as per instructions on Lexmark's site but I don't see any obstructions of any type. Been through their entire checklist. I may just want to get this one replaced. After checking it again and again turns out it is the drum that is not properly aligned within its brackets.I bought this to replace a Lexmark 250dn that I have had for 10 years. But disappointed with the issues in this new machine. Sending it back.

title: Great for Personal Use
body: This is a nice little printer. I just work at home and am a writer, so I print out stories and whatnot from time to time (along with forms, concert tickets, etc.), and this works great for my purposes.It's easy to set up, and toner is the best. I'm never going back to ink. This cartridge theoretically prints an insane number of pages, and I certainly haven't run out yet.I've always had small printers that have held less than a full ream of paper, so that's no big deal for me. I have a whole tech stand area with the printer and different chargers and whatnot, so I just keep a few reams of paper there to refill as necessary.For the price, I'd say this is a very solid toner printer. If you're looking for a business printer, you might want to get fancier. But it's definitely a way better deal than even a free ink printer, because this will last you far longer!

title: Great printer!
body: Have used it for 2 months - LOVE IT! So quick for 1st print.Would definitely recommend and I'd do it again.

title: Fast, Great Print Quality, Lots of Features
body: The Lexmark B2442DW monochrome Laser printer is a good compact printer with lots of features.The setup is remarkably easy. The instructions are basically pictures, with minimal written instructions. Once you remove all the packing material â€“ and there is some around the print drum â€“ then the printer actually walks you through the setup, language, date/time and time zone.You can connect wireless, via network or USB cable. Iâ€™m using this printer on a stand-alone basis, so I choose to connect via USB cable. The computer recognized the printer and it was ready to print in less than a minute â€“ no set up or driver installation required.The printer will print double sided â€“ but I have never had the need to use this feature, so it is not that important to me.The tray will only hold 250 sheets of paper â€“ again, this is not a real issue for me. Most of my print jobs are less than a dozen pages and even the large jobs are less than 150 pages.All printer companies use the â€œGillette Modelâ€ â€“ price the printer very low and then make their money on the print cartridges. This model comes with a starter print cartridge which should yield about 2,500 copies. After that, you can buy the standard cartridge which will yield 3,000 copies (current price around $90) or the high yield that gives 6,000 copies (current price around $150).The print quality is great â€“ it is laser â€“ much better than inkjet. The speed is fantastic â€“ up to 42 pages per minute, depending on what you are printing.If you are looking for a quality laser printer and a very reasonable price, this should deserve a good look.

title: Easy set up, but non-business user friendly 250 sheet tray + dumb controls to control feed trays
body: I have used a B&W laser printer for my daily work for about 15 years now. This is probably my fourth or fifth I've used during that time.There are five issues that are paramount: Ease of setup, ease of use, cost of use, features, and reliability/longevity of the printer.For ease of setup this Lexmark was as good or better than any other printer I've used. I had this up and running in minutes. Very easy. So far everything has seemed fairly intuitive. So five stars for setup.Ease of use was a different matter. I've had two big issues with this printer.One, the printer requires you to go into the controls to switch between the feed tray and the manual feeder. In my business I print packing lists on a full sheet and postage labels on a half sheet. The former uses the regular tray, the latter the manual tray. On all other printers I've used the printer has automatically switched between the two based on whether or not there was paper in the manual tray. If no paper was in the manual tray the printer goes to the regular tray. This printer doesn't do that. You have to switch back and forth using the controls and this is a major hassle. What were they thinking?!This printer also lacks a major feature. This model comes with a 250 sheet tray. Iâ€™m baffled and disgusted by this. Serious users buy reams of paper - a ream is 500 sheets. I see this flaw as a major detraction for anyone wanting to use this printer in a small office setting. I donâ€™t want to have to keep filling the sheet tray. Making matters worse, it looks as if buying a 500 sheet tray costs over $100. Really not acceptable for a B&W laser printer that is clearly meant for daily use.Cost of use: I canâ€™t really comment on this at this time other than to say the Lexmark branded toner cartridges seem to be on par with other brands. Donâ€™t know yet about the price of off-brand toner.The one major positive in this category is the longevity of the drum/imager. Lexmark claims that it will last up to 60,000 pages which is a lot higher than the Brother laser printer I was using. Brother has a real scam going on with at least some of their current laser printers as their drums need replacing after perhaps 10,000 to 20,000 pages. Two drum replacements and youâ€™ve basically spent the same amount as buying a new printer. Ridiculous. So if Lexmarkâ€™s claim is true this is a major positive.As for reliability, I obviously canâ€™t really comment on that. Iâ€™ve found that modern printers are total junk in this category compared to just 10 years ago. Manufacturers are making printers to fail early. However, Lexmarkâ€™s claim of 60,000 pages for replacing the imaging unit gives me high hopes for this model. Crossing fingers.Iâ€™m giving this printer 5 stars for ease of use and the imaging unit replacement estimate. Iâ€™m giving it 2 stars for the horrible 250 sheet tray and the dumb user interface requiring the use to go into the to controls to switch between the feed trays. So 3 stars overall.

title: Works well hardwired. Wireless? Not so much.
body: Writing this is almost as complex as connecting this printer to my network.Â  I followed the directions and used the printerâ€™s menu to connect the printer to my wireless network. I was able to go through the entire setup successfully but when I completed the process the display showed itâ€™s IP address as 0.0.0.0 â€œNot Connectedâ€. The printer would not connect to my wireless network.Â  I went through this setup five times, slightly more frustrated but also insecure, and each time it would find my network and allow me to input the password to connect.Â  After an hour or so I decided to take it to my office where itâ€™s less likely to become a nap spot for the cat and I hardwired it to my network.Â  From there I was able to connect. At last.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The first thing I did was to log into the Web Service and try again to set up the wireless.Â  I noticed that all the information I had entered from the printer was already in Network settings.Â  Seeing that it was all there and correct, I unplugged the network cable to connect via wireless.Â  No connection.Â  The display on the printer said â€œNot Connectedâ€ and the IP address was 0.0.0.0. I wonâ€™t tell you what I said.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  After an appropriate amount of cursing I plugged the wire back in and logged back into the printer to go through the wireless set up again.Â  Even after setting the printer with a Static IP address, one that I chose myself, I was still unable to connect via wireless.Â  So I shut it down and went to do something else. Like kick the cat through a fan. Or set fire to Alexa.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The next morning, fortified by a nightâ€™s sleep, a shower and a cup of Sumatra coffee, I fired everything back up. I was hopeful. I felt optimism and strength. But still it wouldnâ€™t connect via wireless.Â  I connected the cable andÂ  logged back in toÂ  double check my settings.Â  I only changed the IP address to the next number in line from the wired connection.Â  I pulled the network cable and muttered an old limerick under my breath. That did it. it was able to connect via wireless.Â  Iâ€™m still not sure what the issue was since the only thing different that morning was a new IP address, everything else remained the same. But I donâ€™t question why when the good *or* bad happens.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  So now that I was connected via wireless I decided to run a few tests.Â  My first print test was a single page and I was impressed with the speed of the print job.Â  It was much faster than I expected for a printer this size.Â  So I decided to do a 12 page document and time it.Â  My first attempt errored out when the printer wouldnâ€™t wake up to the print request.Â  So I cancelled the job, rebooted, and tried again.Â  As I waited I spilled coffee on my shirt and blamed the Lexmark, whom I have since begun to call Lex, suggesting various warm places it could go if it didnâ€™t work. This time it accepted the job. After 1:40:74 minutes my twelve page, double sided print job was done.Â  But I noticed that after printing a page front and back it would pause for ten to twelve seconds before kicking out the next double sided page. It repeated this behavior until all six pages were done. But they were done. It was nearly 11:00am.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Another coffee. A clean shirt. I chose to connect with the cable and time the same print job. This time is printed 4 pages and then paused for 15-20 seconds before kicking out the last 2 pages.Â  Still it was much faster at 54:89 seconds.Â  This time the pause was long enough to give me concern that the print job had crashed. I was rather pessimistic by this time. But finally out it came.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  After that I thought to do another print test but this time I would use my five year old, Brother HL-2270DW laser printer to compare the speeds. I was able to print the twelve page, double sided document in 1:17:04 minutes via wireless connection with no pause between pages. I took some time away from all of it and wrote a song about Mesopotamian farmers.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Over the course of many days I have been using this Lexmark for all of my print jobs.Â  Yesterday alone I printed a total of 37 pages in 10 jobs.Â  More than once the printer would pause between pages. Oddly it wasnâ€™t consistent; sometimes it paused after one page print; sometimes it was after two or three pages.Â  The first page always slides out quickly, like an ATM dispenser in a dark alley. But after an encouraging start it became a crap shoot.Â  The pause was not the same every time either.Â  On one print of just two pages the pause was close to a minute and I got up, crossed the room- this time with a rubber mallet and clenched jaw- thinking the printer had crashed.Â Just as I reached it it blipped, burped and resumed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  My next test was to try everything on the wired connection.Â Feeling more confident, even thinking I could get used to the Lexmark, I plugged the cable in, switching it over to Wire Connection with a good IP address on the printer display.Â  I hit â€œprintâ€. Nothing. It. wouldnâ€™t. print.Â  I sincerely considered eating one of my wifeâ€™s Xanax and putting out a yoga mat with â€œDark Side of the Moon.â€ Instead I did a breathing thing I use for singing warm-ups. The Lexmark print que listed the job but it was waiting for the printer to accept it.Â  It never did.Â  I had to power the printer down and reboot it for the wired connection to work properly.Â  Once connected, I retried my print jobs and there was no connection issues or a pause between pages.Â  A 25 page print job went through quickly and cleanly. I swear there were tears in my eyes. I even rubbed the cat and sang a little Sondheim. I waited a few weeks to write this, feeling that my initial relationship with Lex (a name I stumbled onto hoping for a more congenial relationship) might cause me to pepper this review with various words that would offend or, at the very least, tarnish my reputation here on Vine. So this review is written with a staid and honest attitude. And not because I took one of my wifeâ€™s pills.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Dealing with the toner was very easy and I can see that when the time comes to replace it that will go smoothly.Â  Over all it seems to be well made and sturdy; nothing flimsy.Â  I also like the second paper feed that allows me to change paper type without emptying the drawer.Â  My Brother Printer does not have this feature and it would have been nice to have a few times over the years.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  I suspect that there is a defect in this unit, most likely in the wireless card.Â Thatâ€™s the only reasonable explanation for the issues Iâ€™ve had. I suggest asking questions about this issue to the manufacturer and to others who own this model. When itâ€™s hardwired to my network I find it to be a nice printer that would work well for home or small business.Â  Truthfully, if I had purchased this I would return it as defective and accepted another unit to replace it.Â  If that one worked I would keep it and be a very satisfied customer. If it didnâ€™t I think Iâ€™d self commit to a psychiatric hospital. With the cat.

title: Great quality and amazingly easy setup make this a great buy
body: The printing quality is very high and looks great, but to me the most important part of a printer is ease of use considering how much of a pain they often are. This printer was extremely easy to setup and to start printing (even over wifi), it comes with an app that you download on your phone to configure it and I had it up and printing within about 10 minutes of opening the box. It is a tad bulky but it looks quite nice and prints quickly. Definitely 5 stars based mostly on the ease of use alone.

title: Don't buy!
body: B2338. Don't buy if you expect easy wireless. Ours found the wifi ok but wouldn't print unless wired up. Was told bytech support buy cables to update drivers on printer itself. 45 extra dollars later only works if wired up despite saying connected on printer. Return is a process also have to go through 3rd party. Bought another brand. Do not buy!

title: Great printer
body: Great printer easy install and goes right to work and much faster than the old one very happy woth it so far

title: Very fast
body: Everyone is surprised that it is so fast. The printer comes with a starter cartridge, not a full cartridge as some do.

title: One hitch, otherwise great printer.
body: This printer was a great bargain at the price. The print quality is excellent. I have yet to buy a new cartridge which I hear are quite expensive, but for the money Iâ€™m willing to pay that price. One bothersome thing for me is getting this printer to come out of sleep mode. There must be a setting, however currently it is a pain to get up turn it off then turn it back on and print your document. It should work by just sending a document and it comes out of sleep mode automatically.

title: Horrible tools. "Virtual Solution Center" is a cruel joke.
body: Unless you are a corporate system administrator who is MS certified, do not buy this printer. There is no way to manage the printer or update firmware. Lexmark ostensibly does this through the "Virtual Solution Center." It requires a plugin for the browser to work. Simple enough, right? No so quick. After the plugin installs, it does not run. Hmmm. I check browser setting and modify one per the instructions. Still doesn't work. Now the troubleshooting has me going into system32 files to make mods. I try that... opps. I don't have permission. So now I am working on changing permissions to system files and folder. What a hassle. Really!!! I'm a tech savvy person and ran the tech helpdesk for a Fortune 100 company, I still wasn't able to get it to work. I could call one of my former support agents and have him help me change all the settings on my new computer - but why should I? This printer is CLEARLY NOT intended for home use. it is too poorly supported. That is unfortunate because it seems to print fine, but there can be no support without the Virtual Solution. Why wouldn't Lexmark just provide an app like every manufacturer.... I have had Brother, Canon and HP printers and never had a problem. I think I will be sending this thing back.

title: Just buy it, you will like it.
body: Great features for the price. Works faster than my old printer.

title: Perfect Prints
body: This thing prints really fast, and dark. Way better than inkjet.

title: Love the WiFi feature
body: First printer didnâ€™t work but they shipped a replacement. Second printer is fast.

title: Very good value, easy set up, superb printing quality.
body: We have a large commercial-grade Lexmark (laser) printer in our home office. My wife wanted one downstairs for her iMac, so we found this great deal. Easy setup, very fast and very network friendly (wireless). Replacement toner cartridges are pricey, but that goes with being a laser printer. Excellent buy.

title: Hard to install for Ipad Air Print
body: Purchased for Air Print feature to use with Ipads. One of Ipads couldn't accept the needed late version operating software. The newer Ipad I was unable to set up. I'm going to give it away since we cab't use it.

title: Toner breaks the bank and difficult to setup.
body: They should give you the printer. It costs $500 every 3,500 copies for toner. No compatible options.For setting up the WiFi, you are asked to download the LexMark app. The App can't be started because there is no way to accept the terms and conditions. The other option is to setup via the keypad. There is no indication where the space character is. I called Bangladesh for tech support and after 30 minutes of trying to explain what the space character is, I figured it out on my own.

title: Excellent Printer- Loaded with High End Features
body: This printer packs a punch with all of its loaded features. It's hard to find a high-quality printer with all of the features this printer and 'all in one' offers. No more trips to the copy store for color duplex projects. Excellent quality output for high resolutions jobs, and adjustable resolution for day to day printing, duplex scanning, and our faxing needs.It's a larger size printer, more height than width. Setting up was a breeze. I highly recommend this printer.

title: Awesome!
body: Super easy to setup!Instructions for removing certain plastic pieces used for shipping were easy to follow. The instructions provided pictures for each step.Had no problems setting up on my 2.4Ghz password protected WiFi network.I was able to setup without using the included CD or the mobile app they recommend. I downloaded drivers from Lexmarkâ€™s website. I have them installed on a Debian Linux distribution, an OpenMediaVault (CUPS) distribution, and on a Windows 7 virtual machine. Each method I got working first try w/o any software bloat. Very happy with setup.The physical size is pretty largeâ€¦. Compared to my Canon MF4890dw.. (see pic). I assume a lot of the increase in size is due to it being a color laser and needing multiple toner cartridges. I am impressed with the build quality of the Lexmark, each tray, slider, handle, etcâ€¦ are all pretty thick and rigid plasticPrint quality meets expectationsâ€¦ hard to describe in words, but perfect for all document type of printing. Donâ€™t expect photocenter quality prints or anything.Scanning quality is superbâ€¦ and I havenâ€™t even used the highest quality setting yet. 200 DPI is providing excellent results, both grayscale and color. Iâ€™ve had some problems scanning in very thin paper into the document feeder, it wants to grab multiple pages at once. I have not had any problem scanning in standard weight paper through the feeder. Has a nice feature when you initiate a scan from a PC, there is an option to either scan immediately, or wait until you select a menu option from the printer. Good feature if the printer is not immediately next to you.Overall, highly recommended this printer. So far the only problem was scanning in the thin paper through the feeder, but I donâ€™t really blame the printer as I even had problems separating the paper with my own hands.

title: Good Multi-Function Printer
body: The physical set up was easy - pretty much on-par with the Epson Multifunction Inkjet that it is replacing. I have it set up on WiFi for now, and expect to directly plug it in to Ethernet when I move it (WiFi was the more complex set-up, and it wasn't a problem). Full color double-sided prints on legal sized paper came out sharp and clean! Setting up the scan-to-email functions do appear a little harder, but I am not sure if that is the printer or Google. I haven't gotten that quite working yet. The duplex sheet-feeder works nicely. It seems to be able to handle a mix of paper types, though I did note that it can't handle duplex on 80-lb paper, and when there is a mix of 20-lb, 40-lb, and 60-lb paper, it seems to jam on duplexing the 60-lb paper, otherwise, seems to work fine. Overall, it seems to work wonderfully!

title: Full-featured color printer
body: The MC2425adw is a great choice for a small office, home, or a workgroup. It feels very sturdy and well-made and has an abundance of features.This all-in-one prints at up to 25ppm, and is rated for a monthly print volume of up to 6,500 pages, so it should be up to the demands of most small offices. In testing, it reached (or at least came pretty close) to the 25ppm. I had no desire to burn through 15 or so reams of paper though, so I can't vouch for the monthly volume rating. Print quality was outstanding and it presented no problems using AirPrint from an iPhone or iPad. Setup was a breeze (with Macs, anyway; we don't have any Windows PCs), both wireless and using Ethernet. The instructions are clear and relatively concise. The Macs just found the printer and automatically installed the driver. If you have any experience setting up printers, this will be non-event. Even if you are a novice, you should be able to follow the instructions without much trouble. There might be some benefit to downloading the latest and greatest driver from the Lexmark website, but in my experience, the one Apple has worked just fine.The MC2425adw prints its first page quickly, too, usually spitting out the first page 12-14 seconds after hitting, "print," not bad for a consumer-oriented color printer.While great as a home or small-office machine, it has a couple of features that make it very comelling for office use. The first is the ability to print securely. If you select this option in the print job dialog, your job won't print until you go to the printer and enter a PIN you selected when printing. This is very useful to ensure that sensivive documents don't print until you are physically at the printer waiting for them. This is a nice feature in any office, and indispensable in confidential environments such as medical and legal offices.The second is the ability to add an additional, 650-page capacity, duo input tray. From the description, this optional tray is a 550-page additonal input tray + a 100-page multi-purpose feeder. I don't have this tray, but it looks to be very useful if you regularly print from a variety of page types/sizes. The built-in tray holds 250 sheets, plus there is the usual multi-purpose feeder. The addition of an extra input tray can either give you access to an additional paper size/type, or just add extra capacity of a single size so you don't have to refill as often. Having the ability to load 800+ sheets of paper at once would be great in an office with a heavy print volume.There are a couple of things that are less than ideal, however. The first is this cryptic note in the "Specs" section on the Lexmark website: "Product functions only with replacement cartridges designed for use in a specific geographical region." This appears to mean that replacement cartridges are locked to a specific region, sort of like DVDs; I've personally never heard of this and am just speculating. That may or may not be an issue, but is something you should be aware of.The second is that, while the printer is well-suited for a moderate to heavy burden of office printing, the scanner and copier are less so if you are scanning or copying duplex documents. It scans duplex, to be sure. However, it does this by way of RADF (Reversing Automatic Document Feeder). This means that it scans one side of the page, ejects that page not quite all the way, then re-feeds it to scan the other side. Essentially, it takes twice as long to scan a 2-sided document as it does a single-sided one. The ideal scanners and copiers have true Duplex Automatic Document Feeders (DADF), with two scanning elements so that both sides of the page are scanned during a single pass. This is not an issue unless you have a heavy scanning or copying volume, AND a great percentage of that volume consists of documents printed on both sides. The ADF holds 50 pages.The all-in-one also sends and receives faxes, but I only have a VOIP landline, so I couldn't test any fax functions. This machine, like literally every other one I have ever owned or tested (which is 7 or so over the last 10 years), just doesn't work with a VOIP line for some reason.The price of this printer is quite reasonable for the quality and capabilities you get. Overall, this is a great all-in-one. I would have no hesitation making this my primary machine in either my office or home.

title: Solidly Built. Good Performance.
body: I received this printer in November and have been printing with it for several weeks now.I have been testing the different features of it on a MacBook Pro and iPhone X.I have always considered Lexmark to manufacture professional printers since I saw a lot of them being used in graphic design offices. My friends who worked there always praised them.I appreciate the opportunity to review this Color Laser on one end, yet I now know that I am a new toner cartridge customer from now on out if I continue to use it.This MC2425adw arrived in a large cardboard box with nylon straps around it and plenty of internal packaging. It was very well packaged. It is a heavy printer with the package weighing in at around 67 lbs. It had to be well packaged. My first thought upon seeing the box on my doorstep was how big and heavy duty the box was.I'm running MacOS 10.14.1 which has the drivers for this Lexmark already installed. It is still a good idea to go to Lexmark's website to check for firmware or driver updates. It is also a good time to register the printer if you want to do that. The latest update is a "combined print scan fax driver for 10.6.8 and later MacOS". It was released on 6-15-2018.Lexmark is a little behind on their pull down menu system for driver selection as 10.13 was the latest choice in the menu. They need to get 10.14 listed. Anyways, this driver works.I found the scanner works best with the Apple "Preview" app. You can choose the MC2325 as your source to scan from the flatbed or feeder. Scans turn out nice. The warmup and processing speeds are fast.The fax function works fine if you have a traditional landline phone. VOIP may or may not work very well. I have found it to be problematic with other fax machines and multifunction printers as well. It is the sending that can be problematic. It receives faxes just fine over VOIP.Copy functions are fine. You can copy in color or B&W. Letter size.Now to the laser printing. The first thing I noticed is how quickly it warms up and begins the printing job. It is faster than older color lasers that I have used. It isn't any louder than the Canon we have in our office right now. It is average in noise level. Not any louder to me. The print quality is very good. Lexmark toner produces vibrant colors and a broad range of color too. The 2400 x 600 dpi produces crisp text and sharp graphics. I think it has a terrific resolution. It outputs around 25ppm and has duplex printing. The starter color toner cartridges that come with the printer are said to print about 750 pages and the starter B&W around 1,400 pages..You get in the box:-the printer-starter toner cartridges-Lexmark Cartridge Collection Program information sheet- warranty card-setup guilde- a power cord- CD software and electronic owners manualIt supports media sizes:A6, Oficio, 7 3/4 Envelope, 9 Envelope, JIS-B5, A4, Legal, A5, Hagaki Card, Letter, B5 Envelope, C5 Envelope, Executive, Universal, DL Envelope, Folio, 10 Envelope.It has these paper handling abilities: Integrated Duplex, Single-Sheet Manual Feed, 150 Sheet capacity output bin, 250 sheet capacity input bin.It has these ports: Gigabit Ethernet (10/100/1000), Front USB 2.0, 802.11b/g/nOverall I have to say this is a very good printer. I have been getting excellent results with it printing from a MacBook Pro as well as from an iPhone. I like it a lot and think it deserves a full 5 stars.

title: Serious small group color laser
body: First, it suits my needs for a task group shared printer. Keep the box and packing if your requirements include shipping off-site.Install is typical which is to say it takes about an hour to get the printer and linked computers set-up. Wireless connectivity is a snap. The full fidelity color laser output on a standard stock paper is primo for marketing and proposal quality production. 800-page drawer capacity is an instant labor cost saving.Note the size and weight to ensure or prepare your planned placement.If you are used to setting up and using this class printer with ink or laser, there won't likely be a problem for you.For gloss photo quality production, I prefer ink. Laser quality photo quality really does require the special laser gloss stock which I've not tried on this printer and likely won't ... deferring to inkjet.Bottom line:The Lexmark 2425 is the latest and greatest in small group laser printing. I love it so far. The transition to full laptop/desktop printer control has advanced and means no intermediate steps to the printer.5-star ... Better than advertised. This is a fantastic printer at a value for money price.

title: Lexmark MC2425adw
body: I have this printer alongside a comparable HP, model MFPM477fdw and I can say that running them side by side, the color output is indistinguishable. The Lexmark is quite a bit larger in size. The Lexmark cartridges are different than your typical HP and cost a bit more. My local toner guy says he can refill them so I'm not concerned. I can't comment on the yield as I'm still on the starter cartridges that were included. The Lexmark has all the features you come to expect in a desktop color laser these days. You can insert a USB drive and print directly from the divide without computer intervention. It's easy to set up and put into service. I like the fact that it has more actual buttons instead of a 100% touch screen like the HP. This is a robust small office printer that will handle your printing requirements at an attractive price. If you are shopping for a multi function color laser, this is worth a hard look.

title: Laser over ink.
body: I've owned a laser printer for over a year now, and have to say I will never go back to ink. I went through a variety of printer brands and models, and all of them lasted about a year before performance issues began to creep up. Then at around the two year mark they would just fail completely (mostly ugly horizontal streaks that I couldn't calibrate away). That alone was worth switching, but I also hated being constantly told to buy more ink when I had plenty (my HP would go months printing before it "actually" ran out), and also the monthly calibration/cleaning cycles. So far with my laser printer: zero hassle.Now for this model exactly: This printer was intimidating to set up at first, but after a few Google searches was able to finish. Once done, I was able to print, scan, and copy with no issues. Quality of printing is fantastic. So far very pleased, but will be returning to adjust score in the future if anything should crop up.

title: Five Stars
body: Love this printer, have several of them deployed in company offices.

title: customer support was good.
body: works well. customer support was good.

title: No Apple Airport
body: This is the new Lexmark printer replacing the MX410de, the old printer has AirPrint the new model does not.??? What's with Lexmark. Get your act together, iPhones, iPads & Macs are out there by the millions.

title: Five Stars
body: great

title: Works Great!
body: I work in property management, so we process copious amounts of paperwork. This works great and handles everything quickly & efficiently.

title: Five Stars
body: in my opinion, meets all the needs of a small office

title: WON'T PRINT...NOT EVEN A TEST PAGE...
body: If this machine worked, it would be a great machine. But after a week, we couldn't even get a test page to print out. Spent three days with Lexmark support and they couldn't figure it out. If I set it up using an HP driver, it works but only straight printing. Without the Lexmark driver, the machine will not duplex or scan. And the ink is less than 40% and the only stuff printed off was the error after error pages that came off while troubleshooting.So this come down to a driver. I have tried every drive I could find for this machine off Lexmark and NONE of them work.So, back it goes.

title: Five Stars
body: Enjoyed the product very much.

title: I'm not tech ignorant but this printer is a real disappointment. I have a Lexmark CS310 at home that ...
body: Have had problems, have tried to get customer support. I'm not tech ignorant but this printer is a real disappointment. I have a Lexmark CS310 at home that is wonderful. Don't know what happened here.

title: Five Stars
body: Five starsGreat product

title: Move over HP...
body: I got tired of my HP printers breaking down constantly. Of course all of the HP replacements never used the same ink cartridges, so I would have to throw them out. The Lexmark MX417de All-In-One appears to be the remedy to all my HP frustrations. It is built like a tank and it is FAST! I highly recommend it.

title: Great product for price.
body: Works very well. Easy to setup and install. I setup this unit for copy, network print, fax, email and scan documents to our server. I have the Lexmark 511de unit as well, and was able to transfer my email/fax list between the printers. I bought on Amazon, paid $209 on 3/27/18.

title: Not Very Flexible
body: Won't print multiple size papers when mixed in PDF. Lexmark can't figure it out. DON'T BUY THIS IF YOU NEED TO PRINT BOTH LEGAL AND LETTER SIZE DOCUMENTS AT THE SAME Time.

title: Love
body: This Lexmark is near perfect for home office that needs are powerful and functional multi printer. I write for a living so Iâ€™m constantly printing and copying and couldnâ€™t be happier with this printer. I gave it five stars because itâ€™s working great and fulfills my needs right out the box but will update accordingly should things begin to go south.

title: Very capable office printer!
body: The Lexmark MB2442adwe is a great choice for a small office or a workgroup. It is a monochrome printer, so it might not be the best choice for a home printer. However, if you are satisfied that you don't need/want to print color at home, it would make a great home machine too. It feels very sturdy and well-made.This all-in-one prints at up to 42ppm, and is rated for a monthly print volume of up to 10,000 pages, so it should be up to the demands of most small offices. In testing, it reached (or at least came pretty close) to the 42ppm. I had no desire to burn through 20 or so reams of paper though, so I can't vouch for the monthly volume rating. Print quality was outstanding and it presented no problems using AirPrint from an iPhone or iPad. Setup was a breeze (with Macs, anyway; we don't have any Windows PCs), both wireless and using Ethernet. The instructions are clear and relatively concise. The MB2442adwe prints its first page quickly, too, usually spitting out the first page 7-8 seconds after hitting, "print."It has a couple of features that are very helpful in an office environment. The first is the ability to print securely. If you select this option in the print job dialog, your job won't print until you go to the printer and enter a PIN you selected when printing. This is very useful to ensure that sensivive documents don't print until you are physically at the printer waiting for them. The second is the ability to add an additional, 550-page capacity, input tray. The built-in tray holds 250 sheets, plus there is the usual multi-purpose feeder (which in the MB2442adwe holds 100 pages, more than these typically can handle). The addition of an extra input tray can either give you access to an additional paper size/type, or just add extra capacity of a single size so you don't have to refill as often.There are a couple of things that are less than optimal, however. The first is this cryptic note in the "Specs" section on the Lexmark website: "Product functions only with replacement cartridges designed for use in a specific geographical region." This appears to mean that replacement cartridges are locked to a specific region, sort of like DVDs; I've personally never heard of this and am just speculating. That may or may not be an issue, but is something you should be aware of.The second is that, while the printer is well-suited for a moderate to heavy burden of office printing, the scanner and copier are not if you are scanning or copying duplex documents. It scans duplex, to be sure. However, it does this by way of RADF (Reversing Automatic Document Feeder). This means that it scans one side of the page, ejects that page not quite all the way, then re-feeds it to scan the other side. Essentially, it takes twice as long to scan a 2-sided document as it does a single-sided one. The ideal scanners and copiers have true Duplex Automatic Document Feeders (DADF), with two scanning elements so that both sides of the page are scanned during a single pass. This is not an issue unless you have a heavy scanning or copying volume, AND a great percentage of that volume consists of documents printed on both sides. The ADF holds 50 pages, more than most printers intended for home use, which is consistent with its office-focused design.The price of this printer is quite reasonable for the quality and capacity you get in the printing area, so it stands to reason money would have to be saved somewhere, and it was in the scanning/copying functions. That being said, the scanner is plenty fast, so you may very well find this to be a non-issue. However, it is something else you should be aware of.The all-in-one also sends and receives faxes, but I don't have a landline, so I couldn't test either.Overall, this is a great printer, especially for the price. I would have no hesitation to use it in my office.

title: Terrible printer!!
body: Worst printer buy ever. Impossibly convoluted and user unfriendly. DO NOT BUY THIS PRINTER!

title: Fast easy setup, fast easy printing, low noiseâ€”AirPrint for Apple
body: So far, this is a fantastic printer. The setup wizard makes this very easy to set up using an iPhone. Our family has 4 iPhones, 5 iPads, and 2 iPod touches, AirPrint is a critical component for us. Our previous printer is the Ricoh in the second photo. It prints nice quality for cheap, but itâ€™s miserable to use with apple devices.This Lexmark is a perfect and seamless component in our home apple ecosystem. There is one small trick, make sure your device is on the same WiFi network as the printer, otherwise no available printer will show up in your printer options. We have Fios by Frontier, and they provide a wireless router, but we have a much better Orbi home network we use.
